article_title: How Brainbase helps enterprises
text:
While some of our customers use Brainbase (YC W24) to create sales, calling and recruiting workers, our biggest value add by far is removing "papercut" teams from large enterprises.

These teams are usually 4-15 people and grow in headcount linearly with operations, making them a huge financial burden in the long term. Brainbase helps remove these teams by automating their workflows and deliverables while enhancing performance.

If you're also a director or manager feeling stuck trying to implement AI in your business, read more about how you can get unstuck in our latest blog post:

The biggest winners of the #AI hype are consultancies. Seems like Accenture even outpaced OpenAI in terms of revenue!

Getting to power (as an AE), as we know it, is dying. But it is possible to keep it alive. Here’s how:

Last week, I mentioned Todd Busler’s post where he highlighted that the number of individuals with the ability to sign off on a deal has dropped from 15-20 → 3 in the past few years. 

As a sales community, we HAVE to think about power differently in order to survive (and hit quota).  

It was never about you or me getting our deals done.

It's always been about the art of aligning diverse priorities within a buyer committee.

Now that it’s such a select few, getting their priorities straight matters more than ever.

That’s what modern multithreading is all about: 

𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦 𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭

Each person brings their own set of motivations — both personal and professional — to the table. Here’s a real-world example:

• Director of Sales → Wants their team to follow repeatable account mapping practices—but it’s manual and being ignored.
• VP of Sales → Prefers to spend more time with family, rather than repetitive 1:1s and inefficient deal reviews.
• CRO → Primarily focused on deal conversion and topline revenue impact.

Recognizing these differences is crucial, as they influence how you approach each stakeholder.

But the real challenge lies in crafting your communication in a way that speaks directly to each individual. 

When you can weave together the individual stories and align them with your value proposition, you create a compelling case that gets everyone excited about signing off.

That’s the magic moment that Centralize (YC W24) makes possible, for every single deal, not just your top 5.

We aggregate all of your conversations (Gong, Slack, Gmail, etc.) into a deal cockpit so you know where you’re not multithreaded, what your key stakeholders care about, and how to leverage your team’s network to get to power.

Want to see it in action? Send me a DM!

AEs: AI SDRs are running amuck and burying that handcrafted email in your prospect’s inbox. Here’s how I’m standing out from the noise (and generating pipeline) 👇🏽

Building relationships with great people.

I know, it sounds pretty straightforward. But with so many cool tools on the market like:

- AI SDRs (like TOPO YC 24 and Artisan from my YC batch)
- Sendspark AI Videos (shoutout to my faves Bethany Stachenfeld and Melissa Gaglione✨)
- Apollo.io’s Enrichment Credits and Power-Ups
- Adam Robinson’s Inbound Led Outbound with RB2B 

It’s becoming more complex, and noisy.

These tools are pretty powerful at what they do. Seriously, check each of them out.

But in my conversations, I keep hearing the same thing: buyers are getting desensitized across every channel, slowly joining what Mark Kosoglow calls "The Great Ignore."

So let's pause and ask ourselves a simple question: 

What can we do to stand out from the noise?

I believe the answer is simple. 

It’s the R in CRM. 

Relationships. 

That’s what matters MOST.

It’s not about:
1️⃣ Send the most emails across 23 warmed up domains 
2️⃣ Automating every piece of the funnel
3️⃣ Implementing AI SDRs that burn through TAM

We can have a healthy debate in the comments about whether outbound is dead or if AI SDRs are the next Oura rings. 

BUT… 

Does it really matter?

At the end of the day, we’re all human, and building real relationships is what matters most.

As an engineer turned CEO & founding AE, I've quickly realized the power (and importance) of building relationships with customers throughout the entire lifecycle — from Stage 1 to Closed Won to Renewal.

Now, it’s the thing I index on above all else. 

I use Centralize (YC W24) every day to know exactly who I'm engaged with, what uniquely matters to them, and who I'm missing.

And it makes all the difference.

What’s one thing you’re doing to build stronger relationships?

After having 37 conversations in the last four weeks with top AEs, it’s clear to me that the winners never operate in single player mode. They’ve found the cheat code:

𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐲’𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐞𝐝 𝐬𝐞𝐚𝐦𝐥𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐥𝐲 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐨 𝐦𝐮𝐥𝐭𝐢𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐲𝐞𝐫 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞 — especially in mid-market and enterprise sales.

Today’s sales environment is far too complex for one person to handle. It’s a spooky world out there — especially on Halloween: endless mazes, dead ends, and ghosts 👻

Doug Landis put it best, reflecting on his Salesforce days — ”a rep should never win or lose a deal, alone.”

So how do you make sure everyone on the team is actively driving toward that win?

It starts with a collaborative culture. AEs are often considered quarterbacks, but what’s a QB worth without a team to throw to?

The top reps are engaging everyone from the CRO — who can open doors to exec-level connections — to team members on the ground who can help surface implied pain and know how to solve it.

As an engineer turned founder / founding AE, I used to be one of those team members. I KNOW that everyone has a role to play to give customers conviction that you’re doing something incredible for them.

Success is never about crossing the finish line solo; it’s about the entire team working together. Effective collaboration improves your odds of winning deals. 

It’s pretty intuitive, right? But not enough sellers think this way.

Especially in a competitive market, if you’re not leveraging the full strength of your team, you’re falling behind.

The best reps understand that they’re a part of a company — this isn’t a solo marathon.

Are you in multiplayer mode or single player mode? Share below!

If you’re still spending 80% of your time in a deal review just getting to a shared baseline, you’re falling behind.


And it isn’t fun for anyone.

I’ve seen WAY too many meetings that consist of redundant questions — it’s tedious and uninspiring for everyone involved. A chore, not a value add.

Every week, it’s the same old routine:

1️⃣ Who have you talked to so far? 
2️⃣ What do they care about?
3️⃣ Who’s missing? 
4️⃣ What are the next steps?

These questions are definitely important BUT it’s not a productive use of anyone’s day. Sellers know that time is the most valuable resource and these meetings are not cheap.

You're losing up to ten minutes per opportunity just trying to get on the same page. At best, you’ll make it through your top 5-10 opps.

What if I told you there was a better way?

The truth is, all of this deal context already exists within your organization. The problem? It’s scattered across reps, coming and going, and tools like Salesforce, Gong, email, and calendars.

Now imagine if you had a single source that centralized (hah 😉) the full narrative for each deal:  where you stand, who’s missing from the conversation, and next steps to become multithreaded. 

That would transform the dynamics of every deal review and 1:1.

Instead of spending 80% of the time just getting to baseline, you could devote 100% to strategic thinking.

Imagine how many more deals you and your team would close if these insights were always at your fingertips. That’s the future we’re bringing to every sales team.

What are the best deal reviews you’ve been a part of? What made them so effective? Share below!

Since launching my own gtm consulting business and working with some fantastic startups, I've learned a LOT of lessons (some the hard way). 

Over the next 90 days, I will share some of these lessons ...

Lesson 5: Creating Urgency Is Really Difficult

While helping companies close out their year, I've been reminded how challenging it is to generate real urgency.

We've all seen it - perfect ICP fit, positive outbound response, strong demo interest... then they stall or vanish. Why? Usually three reasons:

* Cost of inaction < cost of change (change is hard) 

* Problem isn't big enough or it doesn't impact enough people in the org 
(nice-to-have vs. must-have)

* Limited organizational exposure (talking to too few people)

Here's how to tackle this:
+ Reality check: Is the problem you're solving truly critical for your prospects? If not, find companies where this problem really matters - where there's real, quantifiable pain.

+ Get alignment on the problem. You need everyone involved in the conversation to agree that this is a problem worth solving right now (over other problems). Most organizations can't agree on their most urgent problems, let alone department-level issues. Without buying group alignment, you're going nowhere.

+ Expand your reach. We often spend time talking to just one or two people because they're our target persona, they engage, they get the problem, love our demo, agree with everything. But they're never the only decision-maker. You have to know who you don't know who could impact or influence the deal. Btw there's a product called Centralize (YC W24) that can help you with this ... it's really slick. 

+ Focus on "why change?" You need to hear in their words why they think changing might make sense. Getting them to deeply understand the true cost of inaction might get them to want to take action. Most don't grasp the true cost because it doesn't directly impact them.

Pro tip: Address this early. Be upfront. "There is a greater than 50% that you'll stick with what you're currently doing right now. My job is to help you make a conscious decision, even if that decision is to keep doing what you're doing." 

Remember your job as a seller is to help guide your prospect to make a decision because no one likes no decision. 

#urgencyisdeveloped #multithreadnow

8 days into YC, I was in Napa Valley carving a solid block of ice. 9 months later, I finally get why we spent that hour chipping away 🥶

It was Day 2 of the YC retreat, a tradition that kicks off each batch. I scanned the day’s activities, and when I saw ice carving had just started, I sprinted over to give it a shot.

In no time, Nanki Grewal, Robin Seitz, and I were flinging bits of ice everywhere. I chiseled, Nanki cleared the shavings, and Robin smoothed things down.

An hour later, we had our masterpiece: the Y Combinator logo. 

Fun fact: what we sculpted is called a relief. It’s a style of carving where the image emerges, as if it was always hidden inside the block, waiting to be revealed.

Building a startup feels a lot like that.

You start with endless ambiguity, pick a direction, and chip away. Get customer feedback, pivot, keep going. Get more input, adjust your angle. Continue grinding.

Slowly, something recognizable takes shape. A real product starts to emerge.

You keep at it, cleaning up mistakes, refining the rough edges.

Eventually, you have something you’re proud to share with the world.

That’s how I felt after we finished that carving — and how I feel today about Centralize (YC W24).

Every so often, it’s worth setting down the chisel and appreciating how far you’ve come. Looking back, I’m amazed by how much William Wang 👨‍🌾 and I have learned since we began this journey.

And the best part?

We’re just getting started.

Getting to power has never been harder.


Three years ago, B2B SaaS AEs could get 15-20 people to sign off on deals under $75K.

Today?

It’s 1-3 people, if you're lucky.

Todd Busler highlighted this in a post earlier this week when talking about a COO of an $8B public company looking to bring on Champify.

My point? 

Getting to power has never been more important (and harder to do). 

The demand on executives' time is at an all time high, making access to them a critical hurdle.

Todd even put together a webinar yesterday with David Vertin to talk through how Salesloft does this — for their business development team. 

It’s a hot topic.

One thing has stood out in the 100s of interviews I’ve had with AEs while building Centralize:

It’s not just about what you do when you get to power — it’s knowing that you're NOT at power and how you get there in the first place.

In an ideal world, you’d know every key executive missing across your entire book. You’d have a way to automatically identify each of those stakeholders and which external contacts could help you bridge the gaps.

Better yet, you'd be able to leverage your team's network to break into accounts. Without waiting days or weeks for responses over Slack, hoping someone can help.

That's a real game changer: a way to instantly surfacing any internal connection with access to a decision maker. 

And not in a silo — in the same place you understand who you've already engaged.

That’s exactly why we built Centralize (YC W24).

Multithreading into the C-suite isn’t just a nice-to-have strategy anymore — it’s a must.

Relying on one transactional relationship is no longer enough.

Adapt and find internal connections fast, or lose to your competition who’s moving faster and smarter.

What’s your strategy for getting to power in your deals?

Signal and intent data vendors have grown 200% (80+ vendors) in the last 12 months. But none of them focus on the most important stage of the deal cycle.

The messy middle. 

Ryan Neu, founder & CEO at Vendr, emphasized this at a sales talk he gave back in March during our YC batch. 

Most deals get stuck here.

Sure, platforms like Henry Schuck's ZoomInfo and Adam Robinson’s RB2B leverage website visitor data for valuable signals.

They show you who’s engaging with your brand and help you understand your audience behavior, so that you can tailor your net-new outreach.

But what happens after that first call? After you qualify the deal?

Now the real work starts — multithreading and getting above the power line.

Ask yourself: What percentage of your key accounts are truly threaded at the CXO, VP, or Director level? Have you reached the right personas? What does each stakeholder care about?

Be honest. Do you have those answers at your fingertips?

These insights are the difference between stuck deals and momentum. Threading ensures you aren’t relying on any one contact. It gives you a complete view of the decision-making process. 

The deeper your relationships, the better you can track in-flight deal signals.

When you turn all of those contacts and activities into actionable insights, you’re not just collecting data — you’re driving growth. You make smarter plays at every stage.

That’s exactly where Centralize (YC W24) shines — taking more deals from Stage 1 to Closed Won, faster. We turn the messy middle into your competitive edge.

What signals are you currently tracking throughout your sales process, and how are you leveraging them?

Sales leaders, your AEs think their 1:1s with you are a waste of time. 


By adding this one forgotten thing — you’d 6.8x their close rate (and turn it into the best meeting of the week):

You have the right intentions. 

But…

You’re caught in a cycle of Zoom calls (or in-person ones — if you’re lucky) where you’re focused on tactics over strategy.

You’re stuck on the hamster wheel of reviewing Google Sheets, SFDC dashboards and “Next Steps” fields. You spend hours asking questions about deals that would’ve been answered instantly if you had a centralized cockpit with all of the context in one place.  

You do this because you want to:

Now imagine that you have 7 AEs on your team. 

That’s 7 hours a week spent in 1:1s and deal reviews.

You rely on:

You get stuck in the mud asking redundant questions about next steps, handling competitive objections, and negotiating tactics.  

Why is this a problem?

It’s proven that if you have three or more personas on a deal, you can 6.8x your close rate. Just look at the results Haley Katsman has achieved with her team at Highspot over the last 10 years.

But instead of focusing on that, you find out that your CRO wants a skip level meeting with your top AE on the biggest deal your team has for the Q. 

They want to check in and make sure they understand it before marking it in COMMIT on the board slides for the presentation next week. 

That’s another 5+ hours wasted on context hunting when you should be refining your get-to-power strategy.

It doesn’t have to be like this.

Your top AEs already know that these 1:1s are a time sink.

I’ve heard it countless times from AEs on demo calls for Centralize. This isn’t just a one-off — it’s becoming the norm.

We’re changing how 1:1s and forecasting meetings are run.

We want you to shift from tactics to strategy.  

And we’re doing this by giving you a deal cockpit that tells you: 
1️⃣ Who you’ve talked to 
2️⃣ What they care about 
3️⃣ Who else needs to be in the conversation 
4️⃣ How to get to power 

By using 1 - 3 to achieve 4, you can boost close rates by nearly 7x.

Focus on getting to power.
Focus on multithreading.

That’s the power of Centralize.

If you want to see how — DM me.

Long sales cycles that span quarters can be both draining and difficult. But what if you had a real relationship mapping solution?

Imagine having a "ContactGPT" — a tool that gives you the edge you need.

Hear me out:

We’ve all been there. Six months into a deal, you’re feeling like you’re almost ready to close. You’ve spoken to six or seven people, and it looks promising.

Then, at the 1-yard line, a detractor shows up and derails the conversation. You realize there are even more stakeholders you haven’t engaged. 

Now you’re left questioning:
• Where do you stand?
• Who cares about what?
• What needs to happen next?

This is where ContactGPT comes in.

Picture a solution that lets you access and understand every past engagement with a contact — Slack, emails, calls, calendars, even offline notes in your CRM.

It cuts through the noise to reveal what truly matters to each individual — not a mix of internal and external opinions, but their exact words. 

Straight from the horse’s mouth.

With ContactGPT, you can:
• Explore new ideas
• Gauge sentiment ahead of the next call
• Understand perspectives on the value you bring

It’s about speaking your stakeholders’ language and knowing what drives them. 

Not just one person — every key player in the deal.

It’s about energizing them when you solve their shared problems and seeding that enthusiasm throughout the company.

That’s true multithreading, in an ideal world.

And with Centralize (YC W24), that world is finally here.

Be on the lookout for watermelon accounts.


In sales, it’s crucial to keep an eye out for what our good friend, Matthew O'Connor, calls "watermelon accounts". 

These are the customers that seem green and thriving on the surface but are actually red and problematic under the hood.

So, what does this mean?

At first glance, everything looks solid. You’re engaging with the right people, conversations are flowing, and you might even be eyeing upsell opportunities.

But dig in and you realize that you don’t fully understand the current priorities of that business.

Time has passed. 

The deal has shifted.

Are those priorities still aligned with what you’ve delivered? Do your main contacts still care about your solution? If you’re not consistently keeping a pulse on these dynamics, you’re setting yourself up for disappointment.

At any moment, the watermelon can split open, revealing all the red flags you missed — shifting priorities, misalignment, or even the loss of key champions.

You can’t afford for that to happen.

To avoid this, you need to multithread and focus on each individual, not just the account at large.

Don’t rely on a single contact. Engage with multiple stakeholders, continuously assess their needs, and ensure alignment with your offering. This keeps you in the loop and ready to adapt as things evolve.

By multithreading and staying attuned to the account’s dynamics, you’ll ensure that every account is green all the way through.

As the relationship gardeners, we use Centralize (YC W24) every day ourselves to keep our harvest clear of watermelons.

What’s your approach to avoiding watermelons in your pipeline?

I hosted a dinner with 17 B2B SaaS revenue leaders at #GTM2024 in Austin on Wednesday. 


Here are the 5 most interesting (and surprising) things I learned:

1️⃣ 27% more deals now require C-level sign-off

In the post-ZIRP era, teams are focused on cutting costs, drastically shifting decision-making. 

With 138,000 tech layoffs since January (per layoffs.fyi), C-levels are closely watching the market and less likely to delegate purchasing power.

2️⃣ Deals won’t progress if they aren’t multithreaded 

Finding ways to get to power is the most important factor to winning a deal.
 
Mapping internal networks and uncovering exec connections (via LinkedIn) has become a winning strategy.

3️⃣ Internal competition for budget is fierce

Cross-department buy-in is critical. Every leader is competing for the same resources, so make your solution their top priority. 

Even better, solve broader problems across multiple functions, and get joint budget.

4️⃣ Procurement can’t approve your deal, but they can kill it

Most teams treat procurement as an afterthought but getting them involved early removes last-minute roadblocks.

5️⃣ The SPICED framework by Winning by Design is more relevant than ever 

SPICED (Situation, Pain, Impact, Critical Event, Decision) is essential for uncovering gaps in deals. Thanks 🐶 Jacco van der Kooij and team! BANT and MEDDIC feel outdated in this climate.

__

In 2020, when we were all flying high on cloud nine — selling felt easier. 

It was.  

But the times of working a single-threaded deal with your champion (who owned the budget and had decision making power) are dead.

With more C-level involvement, multithreading and getting to the real decision-makers are now essential.

Identifying where we need to shift from single-threaded to multithreaded, and pinpointing exactly who we need to reach.

Event season is over. It’s time to focus on closing out Q4 by getting to power on every deal.

Track multithreading metrics across every level of your business, accurately forecast engagement risk, auto-generate stakeholder maps, and level up your deal reviews using AI.

Grab a packet of seeds for your garden and cultivate them just like we help you cultivate your customer relationships!

After 50+ conversations with B2B SaaS revenue leaders, I’ve learned 6 things that were surprising (and controversial):

1. All of GTM should have the same context at all times across accounts.

• Sales, marketing and CS often operate in silos when they should be a united front to prospects 
• Lack of real-time visibility into accounts creates hours of tedious handoff, a game of revenue “Telephone” up the chain, and stalled deals
• Julianne Tajuba, MBA, MSPH at mParticle knows how powerful it is when sales & marketing are aligned — it ensures consistent outbound messaging and coordinated ABM campaigns

2. Visualizing org charts to spot stakeholder whitespace is nearly impossible.

• Teams lack real-time tools that map contacts in the same place as activities
• Expanding within accounts feels like navigating in the dark without a flashlight
• The few teams that do have a comprehensive view see exponential pipe (and rev gains)
• AJ Tennant at Glean talked about this at SaaStr — when building horizontal enterprise products, knowing how to move left and right, up and down between functions is critical.

3. C-suite sponsorship is a game-changer. 

• Too many deals stall out below the power line. Get above the line, early. 
• Leaders often wait until the final stages, when their competitor is already there. 
• Matthew O'Connor from Salesforce says it well — “Go up and you can start adding zeros to your ACV”

4. Call prep is more than just knowing names — it’s essential 

• Successful teams deeply understand every participant
• A lack of detailed prep shows, and prevents real discovery 
• Sae Ro from Moveworks and 🏀 Stephen Oommen say it’s all about relationships — you need to understand individual priorities both in and outside of the business before jumping on with a customer

5. Change your mindset from single player to multiplayer mode 

• Top teams operate as a unit, not individuals 
• Revenue growth — especially in enterprise — comes from collective effort, not isolated wins 
• Haley Katsman led the charge on team selling and multi-threading at Highspot, taking them from $0 to Series F

6. Involving procurement early can save a deal 

• Most teams treat procurement as an afterthought but getting them involved early can be the difference between a win and a loss 
• Zai Mohammed, MBA, LSSBB at Talkdesk encourages teams to understand that procurement isn’t the final boss, but the folks you bring along from the very beginning.

My biggest takeaway from all this:

𝐌𝐮𝐥𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐟𝐮𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞.

The days of relying on one persona to close are over.

By engaging 3+ personas with power, you can 6.8x your win rates. Team selling and multiplayer mode is how you get there.

The next generation of overachieving GTM teams won’t win using "old school" tactics or tools...

They’ll win with a focus on relationships, org charts, and multi-threading EVERY deal from day 1.

It’s 2024. Stop doing account mapping in PowerPoint.


Relying on PowerPoint is like depending on Clippy for your AI — outdated and inefficient.

I’ve seen too many reps draw boxes and copy titles into a sheet. It’s a “one and done” exercise that takes hours and goes stale in a matter of weeks. 

Not a good use of anyone’s time.

There’s a smarter approach to mapping that not only stays up to date but also brings your activities into a single view.

Let me explain:

Imagine you’re laser focused on your top 5-10 accounts, but you have another 100 that deserve attention.

Ignoring them isn’t an option.

What you need is an automated, easy way to generate account maps for ALL of your accounts. 

A way to pull in the decision makers that you need to get to and the people you’ve already engaged with.
 
That’s where we come in.

We built Centralize (YC W24) to give you a living, evolving view of your accounts. You’ll see who’s changing roles, who’s moving up, and who’s left — automatically. 

You’ll get a heat map of active contacts, their main priorities, and which personas are missing where you need to get multi-threaded.

As you engage in stakeholders, each contact enriches with insights into what truly matters to them.

Relationships are dynamic; your mapping should be too.

Ditch the static boxes on a Powerpoint slide or Google Sheet. Build maps that reflect reality.

How are you currently managing your account mapping? Let’s discuss! 👇

First SaaStr and Dreamforce in SF, then Customer Success Meetup in NY. Where in the world are the Centralize gardeners heading next? Hint: 🤠 

We'll be flying out to Austin as a startup sponsor for Pavilion's #GTM2024!

Couldn't be more pumped to join Sam Jacobs, Brian Lee🏌🏻, Aaron Leeder 🏒, Bryan Elsesser, and the rest of the Pavilion crew in person in less than a week. It's going to be an incredible gathering of hundreds of the best B2B go-to-market execs in tech — you don't want to miss it!

Joining us at GTM2024 or around Austin?

We're co-hosting an intimate, sit-down dinner next Tuesday with FunnelStory to bring together some of the smartest revenue leaders around. It'll be a night of great food and even better conversation. 

We already have several incredible execs attending, bringing a wealth of experiences across Meta, Amazon Web Services (AWS), Glassdoor, Checkr, Inc., Spekit 🐙, Howdy.com, and more to the (dining) table.

We still have a few more spots left so a favor to ask my LI network: please tag your favorite CROs, VPs, and Heads of Sales in the comments who would enjoy an evening of learning and laughs with fellow leaders. 

If you are one, then it's simple — RSVP! Link below 👇🏽

See y'all in Texas 👋🏽

P.S. What's the go-to BBQ spot that we can't miss out on?

3 gardeners running on 3.5 hours of sleep. 9 hours of incredible programming. 15 minutes of multi-threading best practices. 1 amazing day building relationships at NYC CS Week's main event! Here's what went down 👇🏽

Yesterday, William Wang 👨‍🌾, Aniruddh B., and I had the honor of sponsoring the largest meetup of CS leaders in NY, ever. 

John Gleeson, Monica Perez, and Junan Pang really pulled out all the stops on this one, bringing together an all-star cast of 700+ revenue leaders and ICs from across the world.

In the spirit of cultivating customer relationships — just like you'd tend to your garden — we handed out vegetable seeds to fellow green thumbs like Alison McPhail, Lauren Kennedy, Eraj Siddiqui, Hunter Montgomery, and Sandra Cruz, PMP!

I switched gears to lead a session on how to turn contacts into champions. We covered the 7 best practices for multi-threading accounts that we've heard from months of conversations with VPs and CXOs of Sales & Success.

Shoutout to a few amazing leaders and new friends in the community like Cassie (Brown) Vaughn, Ian Russell, and Derrick Smith II who cheered me on from the audience — appreciate y'all!

Right after the talk, Will and I met the CS legend himself, Nick Mehta! Most memorable quote of the day: "I'm a big trade show guy, been to a lot of them, and your outfits are awesome!"

High praise Nick, we'll take it 🙏🏽

Days like these remind me of the power of deep relationships and community. 

In such a short time, we've connected with so many people who share our vision and are eager to help us help them understand their customer relationships.

We're fortunate to have a stellar team, mission, funding, and the drive to make it happen.

It takes a village (of gardeners 👨🏽‍🌾) and we're just getting started!

P.S. Peep the last photo to see how we felt by the end of the day — exhausted yet excited 😅

The Centralize (YC W24) gardeners have arrived at NYC CS Week to cultivate your customer relationships! 🪴

Shoutout to the Customer Success Meetup for an amazing event ahead!

What happens when no one looks at email anymore? 


Your inbox is already being overwhelmed with poorly generated emails that fail to connect.

John Barrows shared an email last week from an AI SDR that doesn’t even have the basics of mail merge down correctly.

Combine that with Gmail’s link tracking, pixel tracking, and outreach restrictions and it’s not looking great. Traditional outbound is under siege.

Soon, no one will want to open their inbox anymore. Even if there are hidden gems between the noise.

So how do you adapt in this evolving landscape?

Well.. outbound may be dead. It may still be alive. What’s much more compelling to me is: what comes after?

What do you need to do with all of those in-flight deals to succeed?

To close deals, especially in enterprise, you need more than just a cold email blast. People crave real connections. They want someone on the other side who truly understands their needs.

It’s time to go back to basics: multi-threading.

Finding the right DMs, understanding each of their personal incentives, and tying the story together.

These insights might come from a chat at a conference, drinks at happy hour, or a scheduled Zoom — but you can’t afford to miss them.

They're the foundation to build bridges with the other stakeholders you need on your side.

Now, imagine trying to juggle 5+ touch points across 10 personas for every opportunity — and not even being in all the conversations. Sounds overwhelming, right?

Not with Centralize (YC W24). 

We help you multi-thread every deal, so you can say the right thing to the right person at the right time.

In a world where relationships matter more than anything else and deals are scarcer, let’s make sure every at-bat is a home run  ⚾️ 

How do you make sure you’ve connected with every stakeholder you need in a deal?

Calling all CCOs, VPs & Heads of of CS in NYC!

FunnelStory & Centralize (YC W24) are hosting a private dinner tomorrow for post-sales revenue leaders to mingle, connect, and share insights on driving revenue growth from your existing customer base.

article_title: Salesforce Ventures at Dreamforce: 6 Things We Learned | Salesforce Ventures
text:
Dreamforce 2024 was a wealth of knowledge 🧠 

Our team was live on the ground talking to founders, CTOs, and AI researchers. Here’s what we learned...

🌅 It's still early for AI

"It’s becoming more tangible in terms of how to build and apply these systems in products. But it’s still concentrated around early adopters and tech-forward organizations.” – Vipul Ved Prakash, CEO, Together AI

🧙 AI is becoming a workflow wizard

“In the next two years, we’ll see AI agents automating entire workflows, not just tasks.” – Richard Socher, CEO, You.com

⏳ Data silos are AI kryptonite

"Your data has to be in one place for AI to work. There needs to be everything in one central view, otherwise no actions can happen.” – Rachit Kataria 👨🏽‍🌾, CEO, Centralize (YC W24)

🤝 Ethical AI isn't a feature – it's the foundation

“You need to understand the trust and safety needs of enterprises and how they think about privacy and security. You can’t tack safety or ethics on after the fact.” – Daniela Amodei, Co-Founder, Anthropic

🎨 AI can democratize creative expression

"Historically, too many people who wanted to tell stories were constrained because of the technology. They can now use tools like Runway to tap into the creative part of their brain.”  – Cristóbal Valenzuela, CEO, Runway

🌲 AI's environmental impact cannot be ignored

"Some of the most climate-positive models are pretty efficient and can run on your laptop. We should be making the climate-positive models the most prominent.” – Dr. Sasha Luccioni, AI & Climate Lead, Hugging Face

Read about our key takeaways from Dreamforce, and what founders can do to apply them, in our latest blog post.

https://lnkd.in/eKsn6Ybi

Enterprise AEs & AMs — relationship mapping shouldn’t be frustrating. It should lead to closing more deals. Here’s how to ~7x your win rate with one underutilized strategy:

Add 3 key personas to your deal.

Multi-thread.

A few weeks ago at Dreamforce, we had the pleasure of meeting Haley Katsman, Highspot’s VP of Global Strategic Accounts. She was also their 14th employee and 1st SDR — a certified sales legend.

She led their multi-threading initiative and shared a WILD stat about her org: accounts with 1 contact have a single digit win rate of 9% but, with 3+ personas, rates skyrocket to 62% 🤯

A 6.8x improvement. Let that sink in.

So why isn’t everyone like Highspot (besides not having Haley)?

Because traditional account mapping is complex and time-consuming. You have to spend hours across LinkedIn and Salesforce, trying to piece together contacts on an org chart in Powerpoint or Miro.

Only to end up with something outdated within weeks.

Leaders aren’t intentionally trying to waste your time — the best AEs recognize that effective org charting statistically increases success. But current methods are entirely manual and tedious.

So it becomes a chore.

I’m with you. No one wants to spend hours trying to figure out "who's who” from outdated profiles when you’d rather be selling. 

It’s not scalable. There has to be a better way.

That’s why we built Centralize (YC W24). 

With Centralize, reps & leaders get automatically generated org charts of every decision-maker, along with actionable insights to multi-thread deals effectively. 

We guide you to exactly who you need to talk to next and which deals are at risk because you’re single threaded.

Speed up your sales process. Avoid deals getting derailed on the 1-yard line. Close bigger deals, more.

What’s been your experience with account mapping?

P.S. William and I nurture our plants like we nurture our customer relationships 🪴

Centralize (YC W24) is headed to NYC this week for CS Week (Oct 1-4), led by Customer Success Meetup & organized by our dear friends Monica Perez John Gleeson & Junan Pang 🍎🗽

Rachit Kataria 👨🏽‍🌾 is hosting a talk about how to turn your contacts into champions — sharing best practices on multi-threading accounts, inspired by over 50+ conversations with VPs of Sales & Success, CCOs, and CROs. He'll be sharing the stage on Thursday with some legendary revenue operators.

There are a limited # of tickets left. If you're around NY next week, DM me and we'll do our best to get you in. Would highly recommend coming by if you can! 🙏

The Centralize (YC W24) gardeners are headed to the Big Apple this week for CS Week (Oct 1-4), led by Customer Success Meetup 🍎🗽

I'll be hosting a talk about how to turn your contacts into champions — sharing best practices on multi-threading accounts, inspired by over 50+ conversations with VPs of Sales & Success, CCOs, and CROs.

Honored to share the stage on Thursday with legendary revenue operators like Emmanuelle Skala, Angie (Grech) Holt, Nick Mehta, Jillian Burnett, Jeannine Crispino, Alison McPhail, Spencer B., Lauren Kennedy, Shane Hughes, Liz Starling, Tom Ronen, Mikayla LaRosa, Emily Garza, MBA, Veronica Dasovich, Maranda Dziekonski (she/her), and Christina Meng!

And of course, pumped to meet up with my favorite crew Monica Perez John Gleeson and Junan Pang!

There are limited tickets left. If you're around NY this week, DM me and we'll do our best to get you in!

P.S. First 50 people that find us get free seed packets 🌱 Here to help you cultivate your gardens just like your customer relationships!

Isn't it insane to watch what results when you focus? 

A few weeks ago I had no idea who Rachit Kataria 👨🏽‍🌾 was as he wasn't in my orbit ... yet. 

Here's what happened, yet another testament to the power of networking. 

A couple months ago, I was thinking through some of the issues plaguing GTM teams, my own superpowers, and where I could contribute to this community. 

100% of the time when I speak to any revenue team about a stalled deal or difficulty breaking into an account, I hear, "We don't have the right relationships at the account." 

YES 100% of the time. Fact check me on that. 

I've never once heard, we don't have the right type of AI. 🤣 

Around mid-August Andrew McGuire kept telling me to niche down and find my voice. 

So the last week and a half I've narrowed the focus of my posts to the most impactful thing I personally believe is getting lost in the hype of AI, sales tactics, and other things. 

REAL Relationships (shout out to J. Ryan Williams for pointing this out to me, as he said every time he and I spoke, I seemed to bring up that relationships matter to me) 

Because of my relationship with Andrew, Rachit was put on my radar.

When we connected yesterday, he showed me what he was working on at Centralize (YC W24). 

Literally his whole company was centralize'd (see what I did there) around ... yes you guessed it - RELATIONSHIPS. 

Focus is like gravity. It just pulls the right people into your orbit. 

#REALrelationshipsmatter

Outbound isn’t working like it used to. Here’s how I helped 24 AEs in the last 3 weeks rethink how they moved MM & enterprise deals to Closed Won:

It’s tougher than ever to stand out.

We’ve all felt it: Google’s email limits, disappearing pixel tracking... it’s hard to even land in the inbox, let alone break through the noise. Spamming your way in definitely doesn’t work anymore.

But say you finally get your at-bat. Now what?

You CANNOT afford to fumble that deal at any point in the next 6-8 months.

It’s about relationships. Think about it: there’s a human behind every outreach. Not just a decision-maker, not just a sale — a person.

And when you approach conversations with that mindset, everything changes.

Here’s what I told those 24 AEs: you’re not just closing deals — you’re building relationships that last. Relationships that pave the way for future growth and repeat business.

Let’s be real.

A foot in the door is a win, but there are 8 more steps after that first touch. And if you stop with just one contact, you’re flying blind.

That’s where multi-threading comes in.

When you land that first champion, don’t make the mistake of stopping there. That single relationship can’t carry the full weight of the deal. There’s too much concentration risk.

You’ve got to expand.

You need to build trust with the 5, 10, even 20 other key players in that account.

Don’t rely on a single contact. Understand the full landscape—identify decision-makers, influencers, and blockers. 

Build relationships across the board, and your deal won’t just be pushed forward; it’ll be pulled by the trust you’ve built.

That’s how you move from “foot in the door” to Closed Won this quarter.

The bottom line: Multi-thread to hit your target 🎯

I’m going to regret saying this but sometimes I do let strangers from the internet “pick my brain.”

I admit, it is very rare so please don’t take this as a sign to head to my inbox. 

The exceptions are when someone is working a solution that is interesting to me. 

About a month ago I got connected to Rachit Kataria 👨🏽‍🌾 and learned about his company Centralize (YC W24). 

I was interested to speak with him because while everyone is focused on getting more meetings using AI, Rachit is making sure salespeople are making the most out of every opportunity they get. 

I like this line from their website, “Close more deals by saying the right thing, to the right person, at the right time.”

Anyway, we had a great talk. Rachit is sharp and was super open to feedback. We are not working together and I have no vested interest in their success but I’d encourage you to take a look at what they’re building. 

This is a photo of the last time we spoke. We obviously planned to match. I opted for the more casual shirt.

text:
Today, we at Convergence are excited to release Proxy to the world—the first AI Generalist.

We have developed the first generation of truly general agents that can acquire any skill by actively working and learning from experience.

We are building this with a new technology called Large Meta Learning Models (LMLMs), a new class of models that can acquire new skills and improve in real-time during inference. This is made possible by making memory a core component of the model’s architecture.

Our goal is to redefine how we use software by creating AI agents that learn and grow alongside their users. We are thrilled to have the support of Balderton Capital, Salesforce Ventures, and Shopify as we announce our $12 million pre-seed round to accelerate this journey.

Introducing: Proxy.

B2B SaaS AEs who manage a book of 50+ accounts with 10 people per account (500+ people) had an impossible job…until now. Here’s why:

Enterprise deals are complex. You need each of the hundreds of contacts across your book to feel like they’re the only one on your mind.

It’s unrealistic.

You deserve instant context on every contact across your team’s conversations.

But instead, you’re stuck:
• Crawling through outdated contacts in SFDC
• Sifting through noisy Slack channels for that one key message
• Digging into snippets of Gong calls
• Piecing it all together into a coherent story

AI has changed everything in recent months.

You can finally access context for every conversation, person by person.

Understand: 
• What they care about 
• What’s top of mind
• Who the right contacts are 
• How to tailor a unique message 

This is why we built Centralize (YC W24).  

We leverage AI to help AEs build stronger relationships by:  

1️⃣ Automatically creating org charts for ANY account you own
2️⃣ Providing a single view of who you’ve engaged with and all associated conversations
3️⃣ Giving your team a top-level dashboard of how well you’re multi-threaded 

Earlier this month, Brian LaManna shared that his Q4 game plan is to “prioritize on-sites and multithreading, building as many champions as possible.”

With Centralize, he’d easily spot additional champions within the org and better define what his best & at-risk accounts look like.

Relationships and multi-threading are the true differentiators in deals won vs. lost. We’re here to help AEs strengthen that skill — not replace the human element.

What's the best play you've run to go from single to multi-threaded in a deal?

AEs, it’s Q4 and if you’re single threading your deal (and it’s $50K+ in ACV)  — there is a high probability the deal is already LOST.  Here’s what we’ve learned that moves it to CLOSED WON by 12/31:

Let’s get real. It’s Q4. Crunch time.

Every deal is critical, and everyone in GTM (sales, success, marketing) needs to be on the same page. You’ve got to know: Who’s in the deal? Who’s important? Who can block it?

A week ago, I read a post from Matt Green that said that AMs and CSMs reps should just straight up ask for an org chart. 

He’s right — if you can get it, it’s a compass to the relationships you have to carefully build over the lifetime of the account. Whether that’s during disco or in person at conferences. 

At Dreamforce and SaaStr, I felt this first hand. It reminded me how small moments can make a big difference.

But here’s the reality: you’re most likely going to lose 40-50% of the deals in your pipeline.

Why?

Because you’re missing the right people. The ones with decision-making power, the ones who can influence the outcome, or the ones who will throw up roadblocks.

It’s not just about who’s on your side — you need to know who isn’t.

Building rapport and trust in those small, meaningful ways is crucial.

You never know how a 5-10 second interaction could positively — or negatively — impact the deal unless you’re thinking about every little thing.

Maybe it’s the CEO you never engaged, or the VP you didn’t realize was a detractor until the final hour. These are the people who stop deals in their tracks.

Knowing who’s against you is just as important as knowing who’s in your corner.

If you can map out that landscape every step of the way during these 4-6 month deal cycles, your team will have a strategic roadmap to navigate the deal. You’ll have every advantage to move from that 40-50% loss rate to zero.

The bottom line: Identify the blockers, hold yourself accountable, win the deal. 

PS: I’ll put a link to Matt’s post in the comments for you

And that's a wrap on #Dreamforce2024! 🌟

What an incredible final day of insights from our portfolio founders and industry leaders. A few highlights across our entire 3-day experience...

AI's Exponential Growth 📈 

"2 years ago we heard there's gold. Now we've just started prospecting." – David Kirk (NVIDIA), Vipul Ved Prakash & Ce Zhang (Together AI), Richard Socher (You.com), and Jeff Boudier (Hugging Face) explored AI's rapid evolution and its impact on enterprises in their respective panels.

Cutting-Edge AI Applications 🗡 

Julia Stiglitz (Uplimit), Rachit Kataria 👨🏽‍🌾 & William Wang 👨‍🌾 (Centralize (YC W24)), and Sunil Rao (Tribble) shared how startups are adopting AI. Key takeaway: Data centralization is crucial for AI success.

The Future of Enterprise AI 🔮 

Daniela Amodei (Anthropic) and Parker Harris (Salesforce) discussed how AI is reshaping customer service and workflow automation. Insight: AI isn't replacing jobs, it's augmenting human capabilities.

Trusted AI is 🔑 

Arielle Fidel (Together AI) and Kate Jensen (Anthropic) explained why enterprises need to be able to trust AI before they'll integrate it into their product. 

AI for a Better Tomorrow ☀ 

Dr. Sasha Luccioni (Hugging Face) emphasized focusing on AI's present-day impacts on climate and equality, rather than hypothetical future scenarios.

Sustainable AI 🌳 

Peter Swartz (Altana) showcased how AI is driving efficiencies in supply chains and tackling issues like forced labor and climate change.

Redefining Creativity with AI 🎨 

Cristóbal Valenzuela (Runway) explored how AI is democratizing creativity across industries, stating "Every company is a media company."

The imperative of social entrepreneurship 🤝 

Edward Norton and Robert W. (Zeck) emphasized the need for entrepreneurs to focus less on financial maximization and more on addressing societal issues.

We're incredibly proud of our portfolio companies leading these transformative conversations. Their innovations are not just shaping industries, but creating a better, more sustainable future 🙌 

Thank you to everyone who joined us at Dreamforce this year, including our portfolio founders who shared their wisdom on panels as well as all our portfolio companies who sponsored this year's event. And a special thanks to our amazing on-site Dreamforce team, including Matthew Speiser, Samantha Rohman, Trista Myers, Emily Zhao, Tassbieh 'Taz' Hassan, Derek Asbun, Claudine Emeott, storyarb and many more!

Thanks for following along with us. Until next year! 👋
#SalesforceVentures #DF2024

Feeling bittersweet that #DF2024 has officially come to an end 🥲 We made so many new memories and built in-person relationships with leaders eager to use Centralize (YC W24)! But let’s talk about gardening 👨🏽‍🌾

Gardening is all about relationships — the relationship you cultivate with every single plant grow. You have to nurture each tiny seed into a blossoming rose (or onion) and that takes time, energy, and effort.

Sales isn't far off at all from gardening. The best teams know that deals are not won at the account level, but at the individual level.

It’s not easy—you need to understand their pains and needs. You need to know where they fit into the organization and work with them to find the other key people who will ultimately help you help them.

That's sales. Saying the right thing, to the right person, at the right time. And that's damn hard to manage at scale. To get your entire org on the same page and on the same team to win faster.

10s of contacts at every customer x Conversations across several internal teammates x 100s of opportunities = 🤯

Here's the good news: the Centralize (YC W24) gardeners are here to save the day 🧑‍🌾🧑‍🌾 

You've probably seen us running around Dreamforce this week, hugging folks and handing out free seeds. We definitely turned some heads — Mark Cuban, now you know why you did a double take when you saw us yesterday. 

I was even interrogated and nearly kicked out of the Exec Summit because they thought I'd wandered in from a nearby flower shop.

But William and I live and breathe our mission. We love building relationships with everyone we meet and have fun doing it.

Hope you had fun watching our adventures this week — you'll be seeing a lot more of the gardeners in your feed very soon 😉

While handing out zucchini seeds and talking to some of the smartest leaders in SaaS, one insight stood out to me at #DF2024 Day 2: the importance of being "Customer Zero."

At the Dreamforce Exec Summit, I heard from the "who's who" running Salesforce's strategy, marketing, sales, and success — Juan Perez, Denise Holland Dresser, Eric Stahl, Marcie Laderman, and Jim Roth. Their main focus? How Salesforce runs on Salesforce.

Despite all being at the same company, they kept referring to one another as customers of one another. More importantly, they called themselves "Customer Zero." 

They're all the Day 1 users of Sales Cloud, Marketing Cloud, etc., which means they have an incredibly tight feedback loop that allows them to improve the product quickly. This is what allowed them to build and deploy Agentforce in months, not years.

We also have the privilege of being Customer Zero for Centralize (YC W24) — we use it every single day to understand how to build new relationships with prospects and deepen them with our existing customers. Many products are not like this and we don't take that for granted.

Being Customer Zero is how we always know how to prioritize what matters. 

Being Customer Zero is how we build at a lightning pace.

Being Customer Zero is how we ship features that move the needle.

We're building the product we wish we had, and now we have it! Part of the magic is being technical founders first — when William and I want something 💥 BOOM it's built the next day.

Customer Zero is an insane product intuition hack and I highly encourage everyone, no matter where they work, to lean into it. 

Let me know in the comments how you do it today!

#DF2024 Day 1 was insane. Salesforce Ventures truly gave us the red carpet treatment for our first ever Dreamforce 🎟️✨

We kicked off with a special AppExchange breakfast led by Zac Cook, Tahseen Taj, and Natalie Roberts. We have the privilege of plugging into one of the only platforms with such a deep ecosystem of natively integrated SFDC apps.

A highlight of the day, of course, was Marc Benioff's keynote session introducing the future of Salesforce: Agentforce. We chatted with Parker Harris, Sanjna Parulekar, and Patrick Stokes after their segments and heard how the SFDC exec team thinks about the future of the AI on the platform. We wrapped up the day hopping between four fantastic happy hours that exceeded expectations. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    
1/ SaaS AI Startups: Met some all-star SaaS founders like Anna Stepura, Dhanraj Parekh, Vishal A Shah, Chris Gorgoroso, as well as sales leaders like Philipp Reichardt.

Ran into one of Salesforce’s best AEs there as well, Nina Zarour and learned a lot about enterprise relationship building. 

4/ Modern Sales Pros: Jam-packed vibe with fellow YC founders like Dori Wilson, Sriharsha Guduguntla and Atul Raghunathan mingling with great revenue leaders. Bumped into Peter Mollins at Nooks again post-SaaStr.

Just wrapped up an engaging roundtable at #Dreamforce2024: "Cutting Edge AI: Perspectives from AI Startups." Our portfolio founders shared some practical insights 🧠 

1️⃣ Julia Stiglitz: "You need an innovation mindset when evaluating new solutions. ROI might not be immediate but you need to make space for experimentation."

2️⃣  Rachit Kataria 👨🏽‍🌾: "Your data has to be in one place for AI to work. There needs to be everything in one central view otherwise no actions can happen."

3️⃣  William Wang 👨‍🌾: "AI applications may not have an immediate ROI but there's strong lagging indicators in terms of time saved and user adoption. The ROI catches up once you have AI in your product."

4️⃣  Sunil Rao: "To benefit from AI you need a good perspective on who is using your data and how. There needs to be more education to understand how data is used."

For founders implementing AI, do these perspectives resonate with your own experience?

#EnterpriseAI
#SalesforceVentures

"AI will automate entire workflows, not just tasks, within two years."

That's not sci-fi — that's Day 1 at #Dreamforce2024 🤯

Our portfolio founders led amazing sessions about AI's quantum leap in enterprise tech. 

Here's your front-row seat to the future:

1. The future of AI systems ⚙ 

Jeff Boudier (Hugging Face) highlighted a paradigm shift: "We're moving from isolated AI features to integrated AI systems." This means businesses need to think beyond single-use AI and start building comprehensive AI ecosystems.

Richard Socher (You.com) expanded on this: "In the next two years, we'll see AI agents automating entire workflows, not just tasks." 

The implications? 

A complete reimagining of how we structure work and business processes.

2. The data imperative in AI 📊 

Rachit Kataria 👨🏽‍🌾 (Centralize (YC W24)) didn't mince words: "Your data has to be in one place for AI to work. There needs to be everything in one central view, otherwise no actions can happen."

This centralization isn't just about efficiency — companies that master this will have a significant competitive edge.

3. AI as a new creative medium 📺 

Cristóbal Valenzuela (Runway) pushed us to think bigger about AI’s role in creative industries: "AI isn't just a tool; it's a new medium of expression." 

He envisions AI democratizing creativity: 

"Every company is a media company. Every company tells a story some way. So you should be able to on your own terms."

Mic. Drop 🎤 

TL;DR: AI is driving a seismic shift in how businesses operate, innovate, and create. 

It's not just about adopting AI—it's about reimagining your entire business through an AI-first lens.

And that was just Day 1 😅 

Stay tuned for more groundbreaking insights tomorrow as we continue our coverage of #Dreamforce24

And follow our on-the-ground reporter Matthew Speiser for live recaps.

Dreamforce is tomorrow and I have to get something off my chest. The R in your CRM needs serious help. Here’s why:

90% of Fortune 500s use Salesforce. For all the flak they get, SFDC’s $243B market cap doesn’t lie. Marc Benioff and Parker Harris have built one of the most impactful SaaS products of all time. Shout out to the incredible folks in our network who’ve helped build that empire: Cal Henderson Matthew O'Connor Joe Teplow Vanessa Gatihi AJ Tennant Junan Pang Dave Macnee Avanthika R.

But here’s the reality: 99% of RevOps teams are spending a fortune — 6 to 8 figures — on what’s essentially a powerful database..

And what do you get for all that money? A repository of names, contacts, and companies — most of which are outdated. People who don’t even work at those companies anymore.

Sure, tools like Gong and Chorus capture conversations and push some data into Salesforce, but it’s far from the full picture. In fact, they often add to the clutter.

And what are you left with? A sea of names, emails, and transcripts to sift through without true relationship management.

Now, imagine this: 

A platform that finally makes your CRM work for you. One that turns your sprawling database into a clear, concise view of every account’s decision-makers and conversations — in seconds. That’s what we’re building at Centralize (YC W24).

We call it 𝐫𝐞𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐩 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐥𝐥𝐢𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐬𝐞 𝐫𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐧𝐮𝐞 𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐦𝐬.

We automatically create AI-driven org charts for every account and overlay your customer conversations, giving you a bird’s-eye view of your relationships. Your AEs can multi-thread every deal — not just the top 10. And your AMs and CSMs will uncover white-space opportunities to drive more expansion.

For 20+ years, CRMs have had the same core problems:
1️⃣ Who still works at a company? 
2️⃣ Who’s missing in the deal? 
3️⃣ What buying role they play? 
4️⃣ What’s been said so far?
5️⃣ What to say next to win faster?

We’ve solved this. And we’re excited to share how at 𝐃𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐦𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐜𝐞 𝐨𝐧 𝐓𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐝𝐚𝐲.

If you use Salesforce, you’re going to love it even more with us on your side.

Let me know in the comments if you’ve cracked this problem — would love to hear your thoughts!

T-2 days till Dreamforce. We were prepping for our talk when disaster struck 😳

William and I spent hours this morning formatting pages of QR codes for the conference — different colors, styles, and sizes. Finally, we found a layout we loved, loaded it onto a USB (yes, those still exist in 2024), and drove 20 minutes to the nearest FedEx.

We plugged in the USB and hit "Print." The printer whirred for a moment, then spit out the first page. We eagerly pulled out our phones to scan the code. 

Nothing.

We tried again.

No change.

Turns out, the QR code dots were too small — the URL was way too long 🤦🏽‍♂️

That didn't stop us.

Determined, we hid in the corner of the store and rebuilt the entire QR code using link shorteners and the Google Slides iPhone app. 1 hour and a lot of eye strain later, we tried again...

Success!

For my fellow Dreamforce attendees, look out for the result of our hard work 👀

And that’s a wrap on my first SaaStr!

This past week was filled with amazing atmosphere, engaging talks, and energizing conversations.

Even though I was only there for 1.5 days, it felt like I’d been there forever.

The GTM talent density at the event was 𝑢𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑡𝑐ℎ𝑒𝑑. Truly the super bowl of SaaS. 🏈

Here are my overall highlights:

𝐃𝐚𝐲 𝟏:
- Landing from NYC and immediately seeing Doug Landis and Andrew McGuire at the Operator + GTMfund happy hour.
- Celebrating the launch of Operator & meeting the entire squad — congrats again Mark Kosoglow and team!
- Meeting Bethany Stachenfeld at happy hour #2

𝐃𝐚𝐲 𝟐:
- Reuniting with ⅔ amazing Customer Success Meetup organizers at the CCO Summit: John Gleeson & Monica Perez. Missed you, Junan Pang!
- Watching Mar Hershenson's amazing talk on how to find PMF
- Catching up with Marty Kausas & Advith Chelikani on Pylon & growth
- Hanging out with & learning from some of the best revenue leaders in the world: Matthew O'Connor, Vanessa Gatihi, Ishmeet Singh, Erica Anderson, Abbas Haider Ali, Dave Macnee
- Reconnecting with friends from Explo who were running a booth: Gary Lin, Andrew Chen, Joseph Long
- Meeting inspiring founders at a Los Altos mansion afterparty: 🚀Daniel Kivatinos, Burak Aksar, PhD, Andrew Wu
- Carpooling with the homies Sriharsha Guduguntla & Atul Raghunathan to the SaaStr side events while talking shop

In addition to the folks mentioned above, Rachit and I were fortunate to catch up with many amazing founders & friends building generational products: Valerie Li, Ann Chan, Akash Ganapathi, Peda Venki Pola, Jacqueline-Amadea Pely, Josh Clawson, Neel Balar, Brent Grimes, Zai Mohammed, MBA, LSSBB.

The energy from everyone I met this week was a clear glimpse into a bright future for GTM. 🚀

Now, onto Dreamforce next week! ☁️ DM me if you’ll be at the event, or will be in SF around Moscone Center — I’d love to catch up!

And that's a wrap to my first SaaStr! Day 3 was a special one — had the privilege of laughing & learning with some 𝐬𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐨𝐮𝐬 all-star operators 🤩

Kicked off the morning catching up with two of my favorite people in the CS space, John Gleeson who was OG Motive and Monica Perez at Notion. We missed you Junan Pang! They're the powerhouse Customer Success Meetup team behind the SaaStr CS Summit this year.

At breakfast, William and I ran into a few of the early Slack mafia who I consider some of the best of the best operators and, now, new friends — Matthew O'Connor at Salesforce, Dave Macnee at Topicflow, and Vanessa Gatihi at OpenAI!

Later in the afternoon, we swapped stories with Abbas at GitHub and Erica at Notion after their fireside chat on post-sales growth. One of my favorite nuggets was the concept of "Leadership Interchangeability" — CS leaders should be able to run forecasts and sales leaders should be able to run risk reviews. Getting all of GTM deeply aligned on customer relationships is the only way forward. It's exactly what we're helping teams accomplish with Centralize (YC W24)!

Then, Ishmeet Singh at MuleSoft joined Abbas, Matt, Vanessa, John, and Monica for an enlightening AMA on all things CS. The entire time, I was just thinking about how much impact on the SaaS world was represented on that one stage... crazy! Capped off the event with more spontaneous chats about life, family, and work with Matt Smidebush at OpenAI and Rob Schmeltzer at monday.com. 

It's a bittersweet feeling to say goodbye to so many great folks under one roof. Luckily I don't have to wait too long for the next opportunity to see several friends above and many new ones — we're bringing Centralize (YC W24) to Dreamforce next week!!

Who's joining us? DM me or comment below if you'll be there 😊

article_title: Building a world-class sales org | Jason Lemkin (SaaStr)
text:
🚀 Just revisited this fantastic sales video for founders from Lenny Rachitsky and Jason M. Lemkin, and it never gets old! Even though it was released five months ago, each watch brings fresh insights when I build my startup: https://lnkd.in/gRkdQWJB

Key takeaways:
1️⃣ How to Balance Sales Requests with the Product Roadmap 
- CEOs think in 5-year roadmaps, VPs of Product in 2-year plans, and VPs of Sales in 12-month terms. To align, give your VP of Sales a set quota for feature requests each half-year.

2️⃣ When to Hire a New Salesperson
- Founders should close the first 10 customers themselves—customers love talking with founders!
- Founders often have deep product knowledge, which is crucial. For example, a sales rep might not fully grasp the complexities of SIP.
- Pro tip: Hire two salespeople simultaneously to A/B test effectiveness. The interview process should include a "sell me this pen" scenario to gauge their ability.

3️⃣ Surprisingly, Not All Sales Reps Want to Sell
- Find those who are truly passionate about sales.

4️⃣ The Value of Technical Salespeople
- A salesperson from a 4th-ranked company might be more effective than one from a top company like Twilio. Technical expertise can be a game-changer.

How to 10x Founders' Relationship

A founders' split is often cited as one of the top three reasons startups fail. Our cofounders in Retell, coming from diverse backgrounds at companies like Google, Meta, and TikTok, bring a variety of styles and cultures to the table. At Retell, we've placed a strong emphasis on building a healthy cofounder relationship and establishing a new team culture.

Beyond the essential trust we share, which serves as our foundation, we've implemented specific processes to enhance communication. Among these, our bi-weekly retrospectives stand out. These sessions are dedicated to acknowledging achievements, expressing gratitude, and reflecting on our successes and areas for improvement.

🎉 Celebrating Achievements: In the hustle of building and creating, it's easy to overlook the milestones we achieve. Taking time to celebrate these moments not only boosts morale but also reminds us of our collective progress.

🙏 Shoutouts: Despite working closely, we sometimes miss opportunities to express our appreciation. For instance, receiving thanks from my colleagues for finding a great apartment for the team was a proud moment. It underscored the value of recognizing the efforts we each put in.

☕ Reflecting on Successes and Areas for Improvement: It's crucial to vocalize our successes and formalize them into processes that ensure continued success. Equally important is creating a space where the team can discuss what didn't work and collaboratively develop action plans for improvement.

I strongly advocate for conducting regular retrospectives with your cofounders. It's been transformative for us. Here's a template to help you 10x your founders' relationship: https://lnkd.in/guJkGdbu

article_title: Retell AI - API that enables developers to build human-like voice agents | Product Hunt
text:
We launched on Product Hunt today 🎉 . Nowadays, LLMs have become sophisticated enough to think like humans, and text-to-speech technology has advanced to speak like humans. However, merely stitching together speech-to-text, LLM, and text-to-speech doesn't result in a human-like voice bot, leading to high latency and awkward interactions instead. Retell offers an all-in-one API solution to address these issues. Developers looking to build voice AI, such as AI receptionists and customer service bots, can leverage our API to effortlessly create bots that interact in a more natural and fluid manner.

How You Can Support Us:
- 🙌 Check Us Out: Visit our Product Hunt page here: https://lnkd.in/gNjWjQmW.

text:
Retell AI (YC W24) is an API for creating human-like conversational voice AI. Developers can build a voice AI like JARVIS in just a day — with an ~800ms response time and the ability to handle interruptions.

Building a voice AI agent might seem easy from the outside: just stitch together speech-to-text with an LLM, and text-to-speech, and you can get the AI agent to talk, right? Turns out it's not that simple. There's a lot more going on in human conversation than we consciously realize. Things like knowing when to speak and when to listen, handling interruptions, and back-channeling cues are natural for humans but very hard for AI to do. Developers spend hundreds of hours on this but still end up with poor experiences like awkward silences, inappropriate cutoffs, and speaking over each other.

Founded by Todd Li, Zexia Zhang, Bing Wu, Weijia Y., and Evie Wang — a team that has worked on product and engineering at companies like Meta, Google, and Bytedance— Retell AI helps developers by abstracting away the conversation aspect from the equation. With the API, you can turn your LLM into a human-like voice agent in a day. It specializes in building the most human-like conversation experience, so you can focus on making your core product the best at what it does.

Learn more at https://lnkd.in/g5skhjpP.

Congrats to the team on the launch!

After spending 4 years at Meta, I am now starting my new journey. At Meta, I met many talented individuals, shipped impactful projects, and experienced tremendous growth. Here are the three most significant things I learned from Meta:

1. Every Superpower Comes with a Shadow
Strength can sometimes accompany weakness. For instance, if you're adept at moving fast, self-driven, and excel in growth, you might be less meticulous in system design and find it challenging to navigate in top-down structured organizations like Ads. Great collaborators, who are loved for their team spirit, might struggle with conflict resolution or shy away from making hard decisions. Early in your career, it's important to understand your strengths and position yourself to maximize them. Later, ensure your superpower doesn't overshadow your weaknesses. It's vital to seek feedback in these areas for well-rounded growth.

2. Influence Without Authority
Learning how to influence others, even when you're not their manager or don't have the authority, is crucial. To collaborate effectively with other teams, find solutions that benefit both teams' metrics, making collaboration much smoother. When helping peers, consider how it can positively impact their performance reviews and create a win-win situation.

3. Listen with Curiosity
When someone proposes a solution different from yours, instead of immediately defending yourself, first listen and understand their reasoning. Ask questions - in the process, they might discover flaws in their solution, or you might realize theirs is better. In 1:1s, if someone expresses doubts about our roadmap, instead of dominating the conversation, listen to their concerns first. This approach can help you address their issues more effectively.

I really love the fast-paced, engineering-driven, and bottom-up culture at Meta. I appreciate the time I spent with my teammates building awesome products. Now, as I embark on my journey with Retell AI, I'm filled with anticipation for the new challenges and opportunities that await. Here's to continuous learning and growth!

I finished Y Combinator 6+ months ago, but these lessons will live forever:

1) Launch early - I've got first 30 customers for Fluently: AI English coach , without even having a website or a fully ready MVP.

2) Money is the best signal that you're building something people truly want. Charge users as soon as possible. Avoid free pilots and long trials.

3) Personally onboard users for every major iteration of the product. This drastically helps us see the product through their eyes.

4) Active customers shape better products - it is so much more fulfilling and productive to build something that people want instead of what you think.

5) Talk to your users every day - we have support chats everywhere, so users can reach us very easily, and I personally read and respond to all their tickets.

6) Set a very high bar for hiring - we interview dozens of very talented people for a position to be sure that we have a tier-1 founding team.

7) Go to market is as important as product, try to hack it - I post on social media and attracted first 10,000 users through LinkedIn alone

My life in 2024:

10 startup lies👇

1) "We grew 300% last month" → We had 2 users, now we have 8.

2) "Our ARR is $100K" → We generated $8,500 in sales last month by offering crazy discounts

3) "We built a revolutionary AI technology." → We use Open AI API 

4) "Our customer feedback is overwhelmingly positive." → We’re focusing on the few good reviews we’ve gotten while ignoring the rest.

5) "Our company is valued at $50M" → Founder’s friend invested $100 for 0.0002% of the company.

6) "We have the best engineering team" → We found technical students who help us for free.

7) "Our unit economics is extremely positive" → We pick out one cohort of 20 users out of all traffic.

8) "We have a highly experienced advisory board." → A few industry experts agreed to have coffee with us once.

9) "We have a strong company culture." → We sometimes order pizza and play ping pong in the office

10) "We have partnership agreements with several Fortune 500 companies." → A couple of managers answered our emails.

PERFECT pitch deck template from  one of the best venture capital funds - Sequoia Capital 👇 

I've reviewed dozens of pitch decks from early-stage startups, and many are either overly complicated or missing key information.

So, what makes a great pitch deck? Sequoia shared a fantastic template:

1️⃣ Company purpose - Company’s value in a single sentence

2️⃣ Problem - Pain of your customer

3️⃣ Solution - Explain your eureka moment

4️⃣ Why now? - Why hasn’t your solution been built before now?

5️⃣ Market potential - Identify your customer and your market

6️⃣ Competition / alternatives - Direct and indirect competitors

7️⃣ Business model - How do you intend to thrive?

8️⃣ Team - Story of your founders and key team members

9️⃣ Financials - If you have any, put it here

🔟 Vision - What will you have built in 5 years

When I raised Pre-Seed and Seed rounds for Fluently, I used a similar structure. So it really works!

If you’re planning to pitch someday, save this template!

Your thoughts?

Sometimes you need to do a little cleanup 😆

When was the last time you did that?

It’s okay to feel overwhelmed. 
It’s okay to feel stuck.
It’s okay to feel lost. 


Remember - we are all HUMANS.

You can’t always be ON TOP of everything!

Pause if you need. 
Take a breather if you must.
Recharge.

But make sure that after all is done,
You come back with renewed energy.

That’s how I’m building Fluently!

How much money could you make?💰
.
.
.
It is one of the most important questions inside Y Combinator application and applications of other accelerators for startups.

So, how do you answer it correctly?

Here’s an example from Fluently application:

«If we charge $25 per month, we need 334,000 paying customers to generate $100 million annually. That’s only 0.4% of all non-native professionals»

That’s all - simple, concise, and to the point. No fluff, just the facts.

After reviewing dozens of applications, I noticed many founders overthink this question.

❌ Avoid these mistakes:

- Lengthy explanations filled with buzzwords
- Missing bottom-up market size calculations
- Calculations based on the wrong market
- Unrealistic or overly optimistic projections
- No supporting evidence for your numbers

Your thoughts?

Let’s make some practice! Using these tips, share how much your product could make👇

That's why I am building Fluently 😅

Who has the same problem?

text:
I have been an active investor for decades, and the growth in the market for vertical generative AI applications is beyond anything I have seen.

Just in the accounting space, we went from tracking six companies that had raised close to $200M in funding to now tracking 56 that have raised $1.5 billion. In the legal world, over 100 early-stage generative AI startups have cropped up and raised $1.2 billion in funding to date. 

Industries like healthcare, finance, legal, and accounting are now booming with specialized GenAI companies, each focusing on specific functions and user needs. Across verticals, break-out companies are emerging with key traits: 
• 𝗥𝗣𝗔 2.0: Flexible and dynamic workflow automation for the enterprise, powered by LLMs
• 𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴: GenAI tools for structured and unstructured data accelerate sector decision-making.
• 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗼𝗱𝗮𝗹 𝗟𝗟𝗠𝘀: Audio and text integration are improving interactions and documentation
• 𝗔𝗜 𝗖𝗼-𝗣𝗶𝗹𝗼𝘁𝘀: Tools for junior professionals to increase speed, accuracy, and independence.

Many of these trends come to life in our portfolio with companies like Collective, PilotDesk, Roe AI, Drillbit (YC S24) and e:cue.

Our latest blog is a refresh of the market we first covered last year in ‘Generative AI in Vertical SaaS: Lessons from Reviewing 1,000 companies’


Special thanks to The LegalTech Fund, Andreessen Horowitz, and Menlo Ventures, whose valuable insights and research are referenced in the piece. It is an exciting time to track verticalized GenAI.

text:
Last week I left my role at EY to launch Delos AI Inc., a startup dedicated to what I believe is the most important work of my life: helping businesses transition from inefficient, manual management of contracts, to autonomous agreements that are executed by AI Agents.

This year marks 10 years since I graduated from law school and started my first job at the Court of Justice of the European Union.

Since then I:
-pivoted my career to tech
-launched one of the first quantum computing startups in the world

text:
If you work in data, then at some point in your career, you'll likely need to parse data from a PDF.

You might need to parse thousands of PDFs in order to pull out invoice information.

Can you trust GPT-4o to do math in 2024? Not quite!

Yuntian Deng tested up to 20 digits x 20 digits multiplication (12345 * 54321 is 5x5 multiplication as an example). The result is that GPT-4o struggles with anything above 4x4, o1 can do decent job within 6x6.

You heard it right, because the transformer model is probabilistic, it cannot even beat a $8 CASIO calculator.

Yuntian's team also trained a smaller GPT-2 (yes, that's right), which, with implicit CoT and Stepwise Internalization, can solve up to 20x20 multiplication with 99.5% accuracy.

This is a classic example of a small, task-finetuned model that is way superior and more reliable than a large generalist model in one task. 

We've been advising our clients that it's important to understand an LLM's weaknesses and strengths. For example, rule number one is to not trust the math done by an LLM, and rule number two is to let it talk more (CoT) than suppress it. 

If you need the right math, do it via SQL.
