There’s a lot of buzz about “founder mode” and how to scale an organization effectively. While I’m not the founder of Snowflake, I’ve been a founder before, and now my focus is on scaling a rapidly growing business. Here’s what “founder mode” means to me:

When I became CEO of Snowflake, I understood the importance of a relentless growth mindset. What worked yesterday may not work today. To be a high growth company, you need to reinvent constantly for the new reality, and complacency is not an option. 

To achieve this level of dynamism, accountability and transparency are non-negotiable. Accountability means setting clear objectives and rigorously tracking progress. I ask my teams for daily updates on our key goals—whether it’s sales, product delivery, or company OKRs. This keeps us proactive, addressing potential issues before they escalate and ensuring we stay true to our commitments. It’s not about micromanagement, it’s about everyone feeling involved and accountable. While we embrace risk, we dig deep early and often, making adjustments as needed.

Transparency means that everyone should operate with the same information. There is no “managing up” at Snowflake. Decisions are made as a team, with everyone holding equal information. And our conclusions are based on facts rather than opinions. I firmly believe you must “trust but verify” - this helps us make decisions in predictable ways. 

Finally, growth depends on investing in people and providing opportunities. We’ve all reached our positions because someone took a chance on us. When hiring, I prioritize drive and adaptability. I seek team players who are committed to collective success, rather than individual gain. People are the bedrock of your operation and this investment in them and in the team is what helps you scale successfully.

The single biggest predictor of leadership success at Brex can be summarized in 6 words: ability to operate at all levels.

Our best leaders can context-switch from setting vision/strategy, right down to designing an API, closing a deal, or writing marketing copy in short spans of time, keeping track of all the details in between. While it’s okay in most companies to hire leaders who merely build teams and delegate work, we don’t have space for pure people managers at Brex.

That’s a high bar, and you may be wondering why insist on it, especially in a company with 1,000+ people. The truth is being capable of writing code, closing a deal, writing marketing copy, or building a financial model — and occasionally doing it — means you’re familiar with the nuances of doing great work at the ground level, which is where all real work happens.

Management alone creates no value. Selling, writing code and supporting customers creates real value. And not just any selling, or any code. Exceptional sales skills, and exceptional systems design is where outsized value gets created. 

We want Brex to be the place where people create the best work of their lives, but if a leader has no clue what great work is, they can’t lead someone towards it. It’s like a cavalry captain who can't ride a horse.

A leader that operates at all levels earns respect from their team. They lead from the frontlines and understand what’s uniquely hard about it, so they’re better coaches. They value craftsmanship, and inspire everyone around them to understand, respect and appreciate the nuances of great execution.

The bar is high, but this is how we’ve seen great work getting done.

Good Sunday morning to my AI friends on the buy side and the sell side. Let's take a look at an article that made some waves last week...

As the title implies, the article is about hedge funds using AI and underperforming the market, and I'm in complete disagreement with it.

The basis for the article is the Eurekahedge AI Hedge Fund Index, which the article quotes “is designed to provide a broad measure of the performance of underlying hedge fund managers who utilize artificial intelligence and machine learning theory in their trading processes.” That index has not beat the S&P 500 over the last 15 years.

I'm going to be charitable and focus on LLMs and Gen AI. In reality, I find it hard to believe that *any* large hedge funds are not using some form of AI or ML in their processes - seriously, no NLP, not even linear regression? But let's imagine a fictitious Index that tracks only funds using LLMs and Gen AI. I would still find that article hard to believe. 

Why? 

1) LLMs save time, lots of time. We built a chatbot to help answer questions around broad trends in the earnings transcripts of the Russell 3k. What companies are worried about recesions? Why? What are the themes? A human could already do this by reading all 3000 of those transcripts but the chatbot saves hours and hours of work. Obviously that leaves more time for idea generation and other productive work. 

2) One layer deeper, LLMs can extract insights from text at scale. That's more than just a time saver - it means a sector analyst can explore and create features that previously would have required serious NLP resources, and those NLP resources are finite. For example, we did this with ESG risk metrics flagged in 10Qs and in two days created a new risk scale from -2 to +2 on ESG impact to business. 

3) Risk and anomaly detection. Risk can arrive in my forms and often times that risk is buried in regulatory or compliance alerts, or vendor alerts around data changes. We have an upcoming case study around this where a trading platform built an amazing system for identifying vendor risk that could be lurking in the thousands of alert emails that arrive every year. Find risks faster and mitigate/avoid them.

More time, more features, better risk management powered by LLMs and Gen AI. I'm not seeing how those lead to underperformance.

Have a good Sunday, 
JR

Companies who try to build a chatbot to solve their PDF data are doing it wrong. 

You may get some mileage out of chatting with one PDF. However, when you have 100 or 1000 PDFs, the result cannot be trusted because of the complexity behind RAG. Just think about 100s of chunking methods we've heard of.

To trust the result, you have to trust the embedding. To trust the embedding, you have to trust chunking. Then you have to trust the PDF to Markdown, and ultimately, you have to trust the prompt and the model behind it. 

Ultimately, you see false positives and negatives and have no idea what to do to improve. 

At Roe AI, we allow LLMs to work directly on PDF documents in raw format without the intermediary pre-processing and vectorization steps. People only need to trust their LLM and the prompt—that's it. 

#llm #pdf

Most (maybe all?) LLM performance benchmarks like Artificial Analysis go in depth on *online* inference. *Batch* inference seems simpler since almost all companies run some form of embarrassingly parallel workloads. But batch inference is different from other map-reduce style workloads. The biggest differences are the use of GPUs and often mixed CPU + GPU compute.

Today, tons of energy is going into improving systems for batch inference, and batch inference is just as important as online inference (companies have accumulated tons of data over the years, and if you want to use AI to extract insights or make decisions based on that data, you will need to process that data in a batch fashion).

A bunch of companies are speaking at #RaySummit on their best practices for batch inference:

Apple: "petabyte scale embedding generation"
Roblox: "efficient batch inference at Roblox"
Uber: "large scale generative AI batch prediction with Ray and vLLM"
eBay: "pioneering next-gen AI platform"
Handshake: "job description parsing with batch LLM inference"

As the context becomes longer, I bet most of the fancy chunking and retrieval gimmicks will be useless.

The scary part of chunking and retrieval is that it breaks the integrity of the whole document, which can be disastrous in the financial Q&A.

Long context LLM can hold many files in the context, so that it does not have this problem. And pinpointing the 50 files is a lot simpler than pinpointing the 50 correct paragraphs.

The retrieval architecture will be much simpler.

#llm #rag

article_title: Snowflake launches Cortex Analyst, an agentic AI system for accurate data analytics
text:
Data isn’t just for data analysts and SQL experts. Too often, these teams bear the burden of being the go-to for non-technical users, creating a dependency that limits overall operational speed. To truly harness the power of data, it must be accessible to everyone.

Today, we are excited to announce the public preview of Cortex Analyst. This revolutionary tool, powered by state of the art models from Snowflake, AI at Meta, and Mistral AI, allows business users to derive meaningful insights quickly and efficiently through intuitive, conversational applications.

Snowflake customers like Bayer are already seeing the benefits. By leveraging Cortex Analyst, they’re enabling self-serve analytics across teams, reducing reliance on IT, and accelerating data-driven decision-making.

Most importantly, Cortex Analyst is designed to deliver trusted, accurate results. We’re setting the standard for text-to-SQL accuracy by:

1️⃣ Capturing semantics and understanding user intent
2️⃣ Creating use-case specific data models to refine results
3️⃣ Identifying unanswerable questions and suggesting alternatives
4️⃣ Evolving over time and leveraging simple schemas to maintain accuracy

"What's the biggest difference between being a founder v.s Software Engineer?"
I used to be a tech lead at LinkedIn and Snowflake, here is a comparison.

Before = my career life. Now = my founder life

How much time do I put on work?
Before: 40-50 hours per week
Now: 80-90 hours per week 

What keeps me wake up at night?
Before: Debug, Oncall, Write design doc
Now: prepare leads, write personalized email, write blog post

What makes happy?
Before: alignment with multiple teams to get a project rolling
Now: alignment customers to get a pilot going

Where does my pressure come from?
Before: deadline and blockers
Now: finding PMF, employees, investors

What makes me feel relaxed?
Before: going for a holiday with family
Now: never

On Roe AI, in addition to analyzing multimodal data, you can also search. I’ll show you a brief example with images. To get started:

1. Create a table in VolansDB with your desired dataset
2. Configure a search index on your desired table columns. You can build a search index over multiple columns, all with different data types! We support text, images, PDFs, and videos.
3. Select the index and enter your natural language query
4. The top rows of your table that match the query will show up

If someone says their "data is integrated with AI," it ironically means a RAG chatbot behind a vector database 90% of the time.

The real deal is

- You cannot rely on RAG to get aggregative insights from a large corpus of unstructured data. RAG is for point-wise data access.
- You need to bring unstructured data closer to the data team. Most are in some random S3 that your data team has no access to.
- You need to enable your data team to do quantitative data analytics on unstructured data with LLM, not letting them build one chatbot after another.

🛑 Stop investing in chatbots; invest in quantitative unstructured data analytics. 

#dataanalytics #dataengineering

Two months ago, I joined Roe AI as its first founding engineer, looking to dive headfirst into the AI and unstructured data startup space. Since then, we've made huge progress. I saw immense potential for AI in this emerging market where no good solutions existed to easily analyze unstructured data. With my background in AI research at Princeton, I was thrilled to join Roe AI—who was at the forefront—to drive meaningful change.

We're using advanced AI to make unstructured data as easy to manage and query as structured data. Through the integration of AI agents with SQL, multimodal search, and scalable infrastructure, we’ve unlocked your gateway to seamless searching and analyzing of unstructured data—no matter the scale.

This journey will be full of challenges, but also growth and unforgettable experiences. I couldn't be more excited to embark on it with my amazing cofounders, Richard Meng and Jason Wang.
